trans-unit.source: Configuring Oracle GoldenGate for Azure
trans-unit.target: Configuring Oracle GoldenGate for Azure

trans-unit.source: Step through a tutorial for setting up and implementing Oracle GoldenGate on Azure Virtual Machines for high availability and disaster recovery.
trans-unit.target: Step through a tutorial for setting up and implementing Oracle GoldenGate on Azure Virtual Machines for high availability and disaster recovery.

trans-unit.source: Configuring Oracle GoldenGate for Azure
trans-unit.target: Configuring Oracle GoldenGate for Azure

trans-unit.source: This tutorial demonstrates how to setup Oracle GoldenGate for Azure Virtual Machines environment for high availability and disaster recovery.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial demonstrates how to setup Oracle GoldenGate for Azure Virtual Machines environment for high availability and disaster recovery.

trans-unit.source: The tutorial focuses on [bi-directional replication](http://docs.oracle.com/goldengate/1212/gg-winux/GWUAD/wu_about_gg.htm) for non-RAC Oracle databases and requires that both sites are active.
trans-unit.target: The tutorial focuses on [bi-directional replication](http://docs.oracle.com/goldengate/1212/gg-winux/GWUAD/wu_about_gg.htm) for non-RAC Oracle databases and requires that both sites are active.

trans-unit.source: Oracle GoldenGate supports data distribution and data integration.
trans-unit.target: Oracle GoldenGate supports data distribution and data integration.

trans-unit.source: It enables you to set up a data distribution and data synchronization solution through the Oracle-Oracle replication configuration, and provides a flexible high availability solution.
trans-unit.target: It enables you to set up a data distribution and data synchronization solution through the Oracle-Oracle replication configuration, and provides a flexible high availability solution.

trans-unit.source: Oracle GoldenGate supplements Oracle Data Guard with its replication capabilities to enable enterprise-wide information distribution and zero-downtime upgrades and migrations.
trans-unit.target: Oracle GoldenGate supplements Oracle Data Guard with its replication capabilities to enable enterprise-wide information distribution and zero-downtime upgrades and migrations.

trans-unit.source: For detailed information, see [Using Oracle GoldenGate with Oracle Data Guard](http://docs.oracle.com/cd/E11882_01/server.112/e17157/unplanned.htm).
trans-unit.target: For detailed information, see [Using Oracle GoldenGate with Oracle Data Guard](http://docs.oracle.com/cd/E11882_01/server.112/e17157/unplanned.htm).

trans-unit.source: Oracle GoldenGate contains the following main components: Extract, Data pump, Replicat, Trails or extract files, Checkpoints, Manager and Collector.
trans-unit.target: Oracle GoldenGate contains the following main components: Extract, Data pump, Replicat, Trails or extract files, Checkpoints, Manager and Collector.

trans-unit.source: To have bi-directional replication between two sites, you need to create and start all components on both sites.
trans-unit.target: To have bi-directional replication between two sites, you need to create and start all components on both sites.

trans-unit.source: For detailed information on Oracle GoldenGate architecture, see [Oracle GoldenGate Guide](http://docs.oracle.com/goldengate/1212/gg-winux/index.html).
trans-unit.target: For detailed information on Oracle GoldenGate architecture, see [Oracle GoldenGate Guide](http://docs.oracle.com/goldengate/1212/gg-winux/index.html).

trans-unit.source: This tutorial assumes that you already have theoretical and practical knowledge on Oracle Database High Availability and Disaster Recovery concepts as well as [Oracle GoldenGate](http://docs.oracle.com/goldengate/1212/gg-winux/index.html).
trans-unit.target: This tutorial assumes that you already have theoretical and practical knowledge on Oracle Database High Availability and Disaster Recovery concepts as well as [Oracle GoldenGate](http://docs.oracle.com/goldengate/1212/gg-winux/index.html).

trans-unit.source: For more information, see the [Oracle web site](http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/database/features/availability/index.html).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see the [Oracle web site](http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/database/features/availability/index.html).

trans-unit.source: In addition, the tutorial assumes that you have already implemented the following prerequisites:
trans-unit.target: In addition, the tutorial assumes that you have already implemented the following prerequisites:

trans-unit.source: You’ve already reviewed the High Availability and Disaster Recovery Considerations section in the [Oracle Virtual Machine images - Miscellaneous Considerations](virtual-machines-miscellaneous-considerations-oracle-virtual-machine-images.md) topic.
trans-unit.target: You’ve already reviewed the High Availability and Disaster Recovery Considerations section in the [Oracle Virtual Machine images - Miscellaneous Considerations](virtual-machines-miscellaneous-considerations-oracle-virtual-machine-images.md) topic.

trans-unit.source: Note that Azure supports standalone Oracle Database instances but not Oracle Real Application Clusters (Oracle RAC) currently.
trans-unit.target: Note that Azure supports standalone Oracle Database instances but not Oracle Real Application Clusters (Oracle RAC) currently.

trans-unit.source: You’ve downloaded the Oracle GoldenGate software from the [Oracle Downloads](http://www.oracle.com/us/downloads/index.html) web site.
trans-unit.target: You’ve downloaded the Oracle GoldenGate software from the [Oracle Downloads](http://www.oracle.com/us/downloads/index.html) web site.

trans-unit.source: You’ve selected the Product Pack Oracle Fusion Middleware – Data Integration.
trans-unit.target: You’ve selected the Product Pack Oracle Fusion Middleware – Data Integration.

trans-unit.source: Then, you’ve selected Oracle GoldenGate on Oracle v11.2.1 Media Pack for Microsoft Windows x64 (64-bit) for an Oracle 11g database.
trans-unit.target: Then, you’ve selected Oracle GoldenGate on Oracle v11.2.1 Media Pack for Microsoft Windows x64 (64-bit) for an Oracle 11g database.

trans-unit.source: Next, download Oracle GoldenGate V11.2.1.0.3 for Oracle 11g 64bit on Windows 2008 (64bit).
trans-unit.target: Next, download Oracle GoldenGate V11.2.1.0.3 for Oracle 11g 64bit on Windows 2008 (64bit).

trans-unit.source: You have created two Virtual Machines (VMs) in Azure using the platform provided Oracle Enterprise Edition image on Windows Server.
trans-unit.target: You have created two Virtual Machines (VMs) in Azure using the platform provided Oracle Enterprise Edition image on Windows Server.

trans-unit.source: For information, see [Creating an Oracle Database 12c Virtual Machine in Azure](#z3dc8d3c097cf414e9048f7a89c026f80) and [Azure Virtual Machines](http://azure.microsoft.com/documentation/services/virtual-machines/).
trans-unit.target: For information, see [Creating an Oracle Database 12c Virtual Machine in Azure](#z3dc8d3c097cf414e9048f7a89c026f80) and [Azure Virtual Machines](http://azure.microsoft.com/documentation/services/virtual-machines/).

trans-unit.source: Make sure that the Virtual Machines are in the [same cloud service](virtual-machines-load-balance.md) and in the same [Virtual Network](http://azure.microsoft.com/documentation/services/virtual-network/) to ensure they can access each other over the persistent private IP address.
trans-unit.target: Make sure that the Virtual Machines are in the [same cloud service](virtual-machines-load-balance.md) and in the same [Virtual Network](http://azure.microsoft.com/documentation/services/virtual-network/) to ensure they can access each other over the persistent private IP address.

trans-unit.source: You’ve set the Virtual Machine names as “MachineGG1” for Site A and “MachineGG2” for Site B at the Azure Portal.
trans-unit.target: You’ve set the Virtual Machine names as “MachineGG1” for Site A and “MachineGG2” for Site B at the Azure Portal.

trans-unit.source: You’ve created test databases “TestGG1” on Site A and “TestGG2” on Site B.
trans-unit.target: You’ve created test databases “TestGG1” on Site A and “TestGG2” on Site B.

trans-unit.source: You log on to your Windows server as a member of the Administrators group or a member of the **ORA_DBA** group.
trans-unit.target: You log on to your Windows server as a member of the Administrators group or a member of the **ORA_DBA** group.

trans-unit.source: For subsequent releases of Oracle Database and Oracle GoldenGate, there might be some additional changes that you need to implement.
trans-unit.target: For subsequent releases of Oracle Database and Oracle GoldenGate, there might be some additional changes that you need to implement.

trans-unit.source: For the most up-to-date version specific information, see [Oracle GoldenGate](http://docs.oracle.com/goldengate/1212/gg-winux/index.html) and [Oracle Database](http://www.oracle.com/us/corporate/features/database-12c/index.html) documentation at Oracle web site.
trans-unit.target: For the most up-to-date version specific information, see [Oracle GoldenGate](http://docs.oracle.com/goldengate/1212/gg-winux/index.html) and [Oracle Database](http://www.oracle.com/us/corporate/features/database-12c/index.html) documentation at Oracle web site.

trans-unit.source: For example, for a release 11.2.0.4 source database and later, the capture of DDL is performed by the logmining server asynchronously and requires no special triggers, tables, or other database objects to be installed.
trans-unit.target: For example, for a release 11.2.0.4 source database and later, the capture of DDL is performed by the logmining server asynchronously and requires no special triggers, tables, or other database objects to be installed.

trans-unit.source: Oracle GoldenGate upgrades can be performed without stopping user applications.
trans-unit.target: Oracle GoldenGate upgrades can be performed without stopping user applications.

trans-unit.source: The use of a DDL trigger and supporting objects is required when Extract is in integrated mode with an Oracle 11g source database that is earlier than version 11.2.0.4.
trans-unit.target: The use of a DDL trigger and supporting objects is required when Extract is in integrated mode with an Oracle 11g source database that is earlier than version 11.2.0.4.

trans-unit.source: For detailed guidance, see [Installing and Configuring Oracle GoldenGate for Oracle Database](http://docs.oracle.com/goldengate/1212/gg-winux/GIORA.pdf).
trans-unit.target: For detailed guidance, see [Installing and Configuring Oracle GoldenGate for Oracle Database](http://docs.oracle.com/goldengate/1212/gg-winux/GIORA.pdf).

trans-unit.source: Setup database on Site A and Site B
trans-unit.target: Setup database on Site A and Site B

trans-unit.source: This section explains how to perform the database prerequisites on both Site A and Site B. You must perform all the steps of this section on both sites: Site A and Site B.
trans-unit.target: This section explains how to perform the database prerequisites on both Site A and Site B. You must perform all the steps of this section on both sites: Site A and Site B.

trans-unit.source: First, remote desktop to Site A and Site B via the Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: First, remote desktop to Site A and Site B via the Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: Open up a Windows command prompt and create a home directory for Oracle GoldenGate setup files:
trans-unit.target: Open up a Windows command prompt and create a home directory for Oracle GoldenGate setup files:

trans-unit.source: Then, unzip and install the Oracle GoldenGate software in this folder.
trans-unit.target: Then, unzip and install the Oracle GoldenGate software in this folder.

trans-unit.source: After this step, you can initiate the GoldenGate Software Command Interpreter (GGSCI) by executing the following command:
trans-unit.target: After this step, you can initiate the GoldenGate Software Command Interpreter (GGSCI) by executing the following command:

trans-unit.source: You can use [GGSCI](http://docs.oracle.com/goldengate/1212/gg-winux/GWUAD/wu_gettingstarted.htm) to run several commands that configure, control, and monitor Oracle GoldenGate.
trans-unit.target: You can use [GGSCI](http://docs.oracle.com/goldengate/1212/gg-winux/GWUAD/wu_gettingstarted.htm) to run several commands that configure, control, and monitor Oracle GoldenGate.

trans-unit.source: Next, run the following command to create all sub-folders from the installation package:
trans-unit.target: Next, run the following command to create all sub-folders from the installation package:

trans-unit.source: Run the following command to exit the GGSCI command prompt:
trans-unit.target: Run the following command to exit the GGSCI command prompt:

trans-unit.source: Then, you need to create a database user, which will be used by the Oracle GoldenGate Manager, Extract and Replication processes.
trans-unit.target: Then, you need to create a database user, which will be used by the Oracle GoldenGate Manager, Extract and Replication processes.

trans-unit.source: Note that you can create individual users for each process or configure only one common user.
trans-unit.target: Note that you can create individual users for each process or configure only one common user.

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, we create one user, which is called as ggate.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, we create one user, which is called as ggate.

trans-unit.source: Then, we grant that user the necessary privileges.
trans-unit.target: Then, we grant that user the necessary privileges.

trans-unit.source: Note that you must perform the following operations on Site A and Site B.
trans-unit.target: Note that you must perform the following operations on Site A and Site B.

trans-unit.source: Open up SQL\*Plus command window on Site A and Site B with database administrator privileges using **SYSDBA**, such as:
trans-unit.target: Open up SQL\*Plus command window on Site A and Site B with database administrator privileges using **SYSDBA**, such as:

trans-unit.source: And run:
trans-unit.target: And run:

trans-unit.source: Next, locate the INIT\<DatabaseSID\>.ORA file in the %ORACLE\_HOME%\\database folder on Site A and Site B and append the following database parameters to INITTEST.ora:
trans-unit.target: Next, locate the INIT\<DatabaseSID\>.ORA file in the %ORACLE\_HOME%\\database folder on Site A and Site B and append the following database parameters to INITTEST.ora:

trans-unit.source: For a full list of all Oracle GoldenGate GGSCI commands, see [Reference for Oracle GoldenGate for Windows](http://docs.oracle.com/goldengate/1212/gg-winux/GWURF/ggsci_commands.htm).
trans-unit.target: For a full list of all Oracle GoldenGate GGSCI commands, see [Reference for Oracle GoldenGate for Windows](http://docs.oracle.com/goldengate/1212/gg-winux/GWURF/ggsci_commands.htm).

trans-unit.source: Perform initial data load
trans-unit.target: Perform initial data load

trans-unit.source: You can perform the initial data load in the database by following several methods.
trans-unit.target: You can perform the initial data load in the database by following several methods.

trans-unit.source: For example, you can use the [Oracle GoldenGate Direct Load](http://docs.oracle.com/goldengate/1212/gg-winux/GWUAD/wu_initsync.htm) or regular Export and Import utilities to export table data from Site A to Site B.
trans-unit.target: For example, you can use the [Oracle GoldenGate Direct Load](http://docs.oracle.com/goldengate/1212/gg-winux/GWUAD/wu_initsync.htm) or regular Export and Import utilities to export table data from Site A to Site B.

trans-unit.source: To demonstrate the Oracle GoldenGate replication process, this tutorial demonstrates creating a table on both Site A and site B by using the following commands.
trans-unit.target: To demonstrate the Oracle GoldenGate replication process, this tutorial demonstrates creating a table on both Site A and site B by using the following commands.

trans-unit.source: First, open up SQL\*Plus command window and run the following command to create an inventory table on Site A and Site B databases:
trans-unit.target: First, open up SQL\*Plus command window and run the following command to create an inventory table on Site A and Site B databases:

trans-unit.source: Next, add a constraint to the newly created table on Site A and Site B databases:
trans-unit.target: Next, add a constraint to the newly created table on Site A and Site B databases:

trans-unit.source: Then, grant all privileges on the new inventory table to the user ggate on Site A and Site B:
trans-unit.target: Then, grant all privileges on the new inventory table to the user ggate on Site A and Site B:

trans-unit.source: Next, create and enable a database trigger, INVENTORY_CDR_TRG, on the newly created table to make sure that all transactions to the new table are recorded if the user is not ggate.
trans-unit.target: Next, create and enable a database trigger, INVENTORY_CDR_TRG, on the newly created table to make sure that all transactions to the new table are recorded if the user is not ggate.

trans-unit.source: Perform this operation on Site A and Site B.
trans-unit.target: Perform this operation on Site A and Site B.

trans-unit.source: Prepare Site A and Site B for database replication
trans-unit.target: Prepare Site A and Site B for database replication

trans-unit.source: This section explains how to prepare Site A and Site B for database replication.
trans-unit.target: This section explains how to prepare Site A and Site B for database replication.

trans-unit.source: You must perform all the steps of this section on both sites: Site A and Site B.
trans-unit.target: You must perform all the steps of this section on both sites: Site A and Site B.

trans-unit.source: First, remote desktop to Site A and Site B via the Azure Portal.
trans-unit.target: First, remote desktop to Site A and Site B via the Azure Portal.

trans-unit.source: Switch the database to archivelog mode using the SQL*Plus command window:
trans-unit.target: Switch the database to archivelog mode using the SQL*Plus command window:

trans-unit.target: Then, enable minimal [supplemental logging](http://docs.oracle.com/cd/E11882_01/server.112/e22490/logminer.htm) as follows:

trans-unit.source: Next, prepare the database to support DDL (data definition language) replication:
trans-unit.target: Next, prepare the database to support DDL (data definition language) replication:

trans-unit.source: Then, shutdown and restart the database:
trans-unit.target: Then, shutdown and restart the database:

trans-unit.source: Create all necessary objects to support DDL Replication
trans-unit.target: Create all necessary objects to support DDL Replication

trans-unit.source: This section lists the scripts that you need to use to create all necessary objects to support DDL Replication.
trans-unit.target: This section lists the scripts that you need to use to create all necessary objects to support DDL Replication.

trans-unit.source: You need to run the scripts specified in this section on both Site A and Site B.
trans-unit.target: You need to run the scripts specified in this section on both Site A and Site B.

trans-unit.source: Open up a Windows command prompt and navigate to the Oracle GoldenGate folder, such as C:\\OracleGG.
trans-unit.target: Open up a Windows command prompt and navigate to the Oracle GoldenGate folder, such as C:\\OracleGG.

trans-unit.source: Start SQL\*Plus command prompt with database administrator privileges, such as using **SYSDBA** on Site A and Site B.
trans-unit.target: Start SQL\*Plus command prompt with database administrator privileges, such as using **SYSDBA** on Site A and Site B.

trans-unit.source: Then, run the following scripts:
trans-unit.target: Then, run the following scripts:

trans-unit.source: Oracle GoldenGate tool requires a table level login for DDL (data definition language) support.
trans-unit.target: Oracle GoldenGate tool requires a table level login for DDL (data definition language) support.

trans-unit.source: That’s why, enable supplemental logging at the table level by using the ADD TRANDATA command.
trans-unit.target: That’s why, enable supplemental logging at the table level by using the ADD TRANDATA command.

trans-unit.source: Open up Oracle GoldenGate Command interpreter window, login to database, and then run the ADD TRANDATA command:
trans-unit.target: Open up Oracle GoldenGate Command interpreter window, login to database, and then run the ADD TRANDATA command:

trans-unit.source: Configure GoldenGate Manager on Site A and Site B
trans-unit.target: Configure GoldenGate Manager on Site A and Site B

trans-unit.source: The Oracle GoldenGate Manager performs a number of functions like starting the other GoldenGate processes, trail log file management and reporting.
trans-unit.target: The Oracle GoldenGate Manager performs a number of functions like starting the other GoldenGate processes, trail log file management and reporting.

trans-unit.source: You need to configure the Oracle GoldenGate Manager process on both Site A and Site B. To do this, perform the following steps on Site A and Site B.
trans-unit.target: You need to configure the Oracle GoldenGate Manager process on both Site A and Site B. To do this, perform the following steps on Site A and Site B.

trans-unit.target: Open Windows command window and initiate the Oracle GoldenGate command interpreter:

trans-unit.target: Logs the GGSCI session into a database so that you can execute commands that affect the database:

trans-unit.target: Display the status and lag (where relevant) for all Manager, Extract, and Replicat processes on a system:

trans-unit.target: Open the parameter file using the EDIT PARAMS command and then append the following information:

trans-unit.target: Create Extract Group and Data Pump processes on Site A and Site B

trans-unit.target: Create Extract and Data Pump processes on Site A

trans-unit.source: You need to create the Extract and Data Pump processes on Site A and Site B.
trans-unit.target: You need to create the Extract and Data Pump processes on Site A and Site B.

trans-unit.source: Remote desktop to Site A and Site B via the Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: Remote desktop to Site A and Site B via the Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: Open up GGSCI command interpreter window.
trans-unit.target: Open up GGSCI command interpreter window.

trans-unit.source: Run the following commands on Site A:
trans-unit.target: Run the following commands on Site A:

trans-unit.source: Open the parameter file using the EDIT PARAMS command and then append the following information:
trans-unit.target: Open the parameter file using the EDIT PARAMS command and then append the following information:

trans-unit.source: GGSCI (MachineGG1) 18> edit params ext1
trans-unit.target: GGSCI (MachineGG1) 18> edit params ext1

trans-unit.source: EXTRACT ext1
trans-unit.target: EXTRACT ext1

trans-unit.source: USERID ggate, PASSWORD ggate
trans-unit.target: USERID ggate, PASSWORD ggate

trans-unit.source: EXTTRAIL C:\OracleGG\dirdat\aa
trans-unit.target: EXTTRAIL C:\OracleGG\dirdat\aa

trans-unit.source: TRANLOGOPTIONS EXCLUDEUSER ggate
trans-unit.target: TRANLOGOPTIONS EXCLUDEUSER ggate

trans-unit.source: TABLE scott.inventory,
trans-unit.target: TABLE scott.inventory,

trans-unit.source: GETBEFORECOLS (
trans-unit.target: GETBEFORECOLS (

trans-unit.source: ON UPDATE KEYINCLUDING (prod_category,qty_in_stock, last_dml),
trans-unit.target: ON UPDATE KEYINCLUDING (prod_category,qty_in_stock, last_dml),

trans-unit.source: ON DELETE KEYINCLUDING (prod_category,qty_in_stock, last_dml));
trans-unit.target: ON DELETE KEYINCLUDING (prod_category,qty_in_stock, last_dml));

trans-unit.target: Next, you need to add a checkpoint table on Site B. To do this, you need to open up a GoldenGate command interpreter window and run:

trans-unit.target: And then, add the checkpoint table to the database, where ggate is the owner:

trans-unit.source: Add REPLICAT on Site B

trans-unit.source: Verify the bi-directional replication process
trans-unit.target: Verify the bi-directional replication process

trans-unit.source: To verify the Oracle GoldenGate configuration, insert a row into the database at Site A.
trans-unit.target: To verify the Oracle GoldenGate configuration, insert a row into the database at Site A.

trans-unit.source: Remote Desktop to Site A. Open up SQL*Plus command window and run:
trans-unit.target: Remote Desktop to Site A. Open up SQL*Plus command window and run:

trans-unit.source: SQL> select name from v$database;
trans-unit.target: SQL> select name from v$database;

trans-unit.source: Then, check if that row is replicated on Site B. To do this, remote desktop to Site B. Open up SQL Plus window and run:
